channel.title: Josh Marks' Blog!
channel.description: Recent content on Josh Marks' Blog!

item.title: Books I've Known and Loved
item.description: A non-exhaustive list of books I’ve really enjoyed and am glad I bought for my bookshelf at home. Let me know if you find a gem! Or if you have a book that I should check out. I’m always looking for a well written book. Electrical Engineering High-Speed Digital Design: A Handbook of Black Magic High Speed Signal Propogation: Advanced Black Magic Electromagnetic Compatibility Engineering The Art of Electronics The Art of Electronics: The x Chapters Massive MIMO Networks: Spectral, Energy, and Hardware Efficiency: Satellite Communications Payload and System Microwave Oven Repair Building Electro-Optical Systems: Making It all Work The Design of CMOS Radio-Frequency Integrated Circuits Switching Power Supplies A - Z Understanding Delta-Sigma Data Converters Analog Circuit Design: A Tutorial Guide to Applications and Solutions Software Engineering Test Driven Development for Embedded C Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach The Clean Coder: A Code of Conduct for Professional Programmers Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software HCS08 Unleashed: Designer’s Guide To the HCS08 Microcontrollers Math Linear Algebra Data-Driven Science and Engineering: Machine Learning, Dynamical Systems, and Control The Art of Problem Solving, Vol.

item.title: Current Feedback Op-amp Testing
item.description: Big takeaway: Current feedback opamps are very particular about external component values. You must choose from the list of approved values in the datasheet or spend a lot of time hunting for an optimum value that gives you the gain and also provides stability. Summary: I replaced the feedback resistor elements with 510 ohm resistors for Rf and Rg. This gives a gain of two and the widest bandwidth, 1.4GHz, from the OPA695.
